quest_title: An a resonance column, first and second resonance are obtained at depths 22.7cm and 70.2cm respectively. The third resonance will obtained at a depth of
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{l}_{1}=22.7 \mathrm{cm}, \mathrm{l}_{2}=70.2 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\lambda=2\left(1_{2}-\mathrm{l}_{1}\right)=2 \times(70.2-22.7)=95 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\mathrm{e}=\left(\cfrac{l_{2}-3 l_{1}}{2}\right)=1.05\)
The length of third resonance; \(\mathrm{l_{3}}+\mathrm{e}=\cfrac{5 \lambda}{4}\)
\(\quad \mathrm{l}_{3}=\cfrac{5 \lambda}{4}-\mathrm{e}=118.75-1.05\)
\(\therefore\, \mathrm{l}_{3}=117.7 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: Three 2 \(\Omega\) resistors are connected to form a triangle. The resistance between any two corner is
explanation_txt:
\(R_{a b}=\cfrac{R_{1} R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}}\)

\(R_{a b}=\cfrac{4 \times 2}{4+2}=\cfrac{4 \times 2}{6}\)

\(\therefore R_{a b}=4/3 \Omega\)

quest_title: A galvanometer can bear maximum current of 25\(\mu\)A and has resistance 5 \(\Omega\). The suitable resistance to convert it into a volt meter of range 0-2 volts is
explanation_txt:
Let \(x\) be the value of resistance to be connected in series with the galvanometer,

Range of voltmeter \((v)=2 v\)

Then \(v=I_{g}\left(x+R_{g}\right)\)

\(\begin{array}{c}{2=25 \times 10^{-3}(x+5)} \\ {\therefore x=75 \Omega}\end{array}\)

quest_title: The magnetic field due to a short magnet at a point on its axis at distance X cm from the middle point of the magnet is 200 Gauss. The magnetic field at a point on the transverse axis at a distance X cm from the middle of the magnet is
explanation_txt:
In CGS system, magnetic field intensity along the longitudinal axis of magnet \(B _ { l } = \cfrac { 2 M } { X ^ { 3 } } = 200\) Gauss

Magnetic field intensity along transverse axis of magnet \(\Rightarrow B _ { t } = \cfrac { M } { X ^ { 3 } }=\cfrac{B_{I}}{2} = 100\) Gauss

quest_title: 1 g of hydrogen of found to combine with 80g of bromine. 1g of calcium combines with 4g of bromine. The equivalent mass of calcium is:
explanation_txt:
1 g of hydrogen of found to combine with 80g of bromine.

\(\therefore\) Equivalet weight of Bromine = 80

Again, 4g of Bromine is combined by 1 g of calcium.

4*20 g = 80 gm of Bromine is combined by 20 gm of Calcium.

\(\therefore\) Equivalent mass of calcium = 20
question_plain_title: 1 g of hydrogen of found to combine with 80g of bromine. 1g of calcium combines with 4g of bromine. The equivalent mass of calcium is:
explanation_plain_text:
1 g of hydrogen of found to combine with 80g of bromine.

Equivalet weight of Bromine = 80

Again, 4g of Bromine is combined by 1 g of calcium.

4*20 g = 80 gm of Bromine is combined by 20 gm of Calcium.

Equivalent mass of calcium = 20

quest_title: Which of the following metal doesn't give amphoteric oxide?
explanation_txt:
The oxides of Aluminium, zinc and tin are amphoteric as they react as both acids and bases:

  • ZnO:
    • as acid: ZnO + 2 NaOH + H2O → Na2[Zn(OH)4]
    • as base: ZnO + H2SO4 → ZnSO4 + H2O
  • Al2O3:
    • as acid: Al2O3 + 2 NaOH + 3 H2O → 2 Na[Al(OH)4]
    • as base: Al2O3 + 6 HCl→ 2 AlCl3 + 3 H2O
  • SnO:
    • as acid: SnO +4 NaOH + H2O ⇌ Na4[Sn(OH)6]
    • as base: SnO +2 HCl ⇌ SnCl2 + H2O

The oxides of copper are all basic.
question_plain_title: Which of the following metal doesn't give amphoteric oxide?
explanation_plain_text:
The oxides of Aluminium, zinc and tin are amphoteric as they react as both acids and bases:

  • ZnO:
    • as acid: ZnO + 2 NaOH + H2O → Na2[Zn(OH)4]
    • as base: ZnO + H2SO4 → ZnSO4 + H2O
  • Al2O3:
    • as acid: Al2O3 + 2 NaOH + 3 H2O → 2 Na[Al(OH)4]
    • as base: Al2O3 + 6 HCl→ 2 AlCl3 + 3 H2O
  • SnO:
    • as acid: SnO +4 NaOH + H2O ⇌ Na4[Sn(OH)6]
    • as base: SnO +2 HCl ⇌ SnCl2 + H2O

The oxides of copper are all basic.

quest_title: Which is the most non-metallic of the following
explanation_txt:
From right to left across a period, metallic character increases because the attraction between valence electron and the nucleus is weaker, enabling an easier loss of electrons. 

Metallic character increases as you move down a group because the atomic size is increasing.

According to this trend, B is most non-metallic.
question_plain_title: Which is the most non-metallic of the following

According to this trend, B is most non-metallic.

quest_title: The angle between \( 4\hat{\imath} -3\hat{\jmath} + 6\hat{k} \) and \(2\hat{\imath} - 7\hat{\jmath} -9\hat{k} \) is:
explanation_txt:
If \( \theta \) is angle between \(\vec{a}\) and \(\vec{b}\), then \(\vec{a}.\vec{b} = ab \cos \theta \)

Using the formula,

\( (4\hat{\imath} -3\hat{\jmath} + 6\hat{k}) . (2\hat{\imath} - 7\hat{\jmath} -9\hat{k}) = \sqrt {(16+9+36)(4+49+81)} \cos \theta \)

Or, \( 8+21-54 = \sqrt {8174} \cos \theta \)

Or, \( \cos \theta = -\cfrac{25}{\sqrt{8174}} \)

So, \( \theta \approx 106^{\circ} \)

quest_title: If a and b are two vectors, then \( ( \mathbf { a } \times \mathbf { b } ) ^ { 2 } \) equals
ans1_txt: \( \left| \begin{array} { l l l } { \mathbf { a } } \cdot { \mathbf { b } } & { \mathbf { a } } \cdot { \mathbf { a } } \\ { \mathbf { b } }\cdot { \mathbf { b } } & { \mathbf { b } } \cdot { \mathbf { a } } \end{array} \right| \)
ans2_txt: \( \left| \begin{array} { c c c c } { \mathbf { a } } \cdot { \mathbf { a } } & { \mathbf { a } } \cdot { \mathbf { b } } \\ { \mathbf { b } }\cdot { \mathbf { a } } & { \mathbf { b } }\cdot { \mathbf { b } } \end{array} \right| \)
ans3_txt: \( \left| \begin{array} { c c } { \mathbf { a } } & { \mathbf { b } } \\ { \mathbf { b } } & { \mathbf { a } } \end{array} \right| \)
explanation_txt: \( ( \mathbf { a } \times \mathbf { b } ) ^ { 2 } = a ^ { 2 } b ^ { 2 } - ( \mathbf { a } . \mathbf { b } ) ^ { 2 } = \left| \begin{array} { l l } { \mathbf { a } \cdot \mathbf { a } } & { \mathbf { a } . \mathbf { b } } \\ { \mathbf { a } . \mathbf { b } } & { \mathbf { b } . \mathbf { b } } \end{array} \right| \)

quest_title: The function \(x^{5} -5x^{4} +5x^{3} -1\) has:
explanation_txt:
Let\(f(x)=x^{5} -5x^{4} +5x^{3} -1\)

\[ \Rightarrow f'(x)=5x^{4} -20x^{3} +15x^{2} =0\]

\({\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} (x-3)(x-1)=0\) or \(x=3,1\)

Now \(f''(x)=20x^{3} -60x^{2} +30x\)

Put \(x=3\) and 1, we get \(f'''(3)=+ve\) and \(f''(1)=-ve\) and \(f''(0)=0\).

Hence \(f(x)\) has neither maximum nor minimum at \(x=0\).

explanation_txt:
For 1st 3 seconds,

\(\mathrm{h}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{g} \times 3^{2}=\cfrac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 9=45 \mathrm{m} \)
\(\mathrm{h}=\cfrac{\mathrm{g}}{2}(2 \mathrm{n}-1) \)

\(\text { or, } 45=\cfrac{10}{5}(2 n-1) \)
\(\text { or, } 2 n=9+1 \)
\(\text { or, } n=5 \text { sec } \)

quest_title: The relation between the linear magnification m, the object distance u and the focal length f is
explanation_txt:
\(\because m = - \cfrac { v } { u } \text { also } \cfrac { 1 } { f } = \cfrac { 1 } { v } + \cfrac { 1 } { u } \Rightarrow \cfrac { u } { f } = \cfrac { u } { v } + 1\)

\(\Rightarrow - \cfrac { u } { v } = 1 - \cfrac { u } { f } \Rightarrow \cfrac { - v } { u } = \cfrac { f } { f - u } \text { so } m = \cfrac { f } { f - u }\)
question_plain_title: The relation between the linear magnification m, the object distance u and the focal length f is

quest_title: The ratio of intensities of two waves is 9 : 1. They are producing interference. The ratio of maximum and minimum intensities will be
explanation_txt:
Intensity of a wave is proportional to square of its amplitude i.e. \(I\propto A^{2}\)

For two waves,

\(\cfrac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}=\cfrac{A_{1}^{2}}{A_{2}^{2}}=\cfrac{9}{1}\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{A_{1}}{A_{2}}=\cfrac{3}{1}\)

When the waves superimpose constructively, amplitude of the resulting wave is the sum of amplitude of individual waves

i.e. \(A_{\text{max}}=3+1=4\)

When the waves superimpose destructively, amplitude of the resulting wave is the difference of amplitude of individual waves

i.e. \(A_{\text{min}}=3-1=2\)

Now, ratio of maximum and minimum intensities of the resulting waves when the two waves are superimposed constructively and destructively \(=\cfrac{I_{\text{max}}}{I_{\text{min}}}=\cfrac{A_{\text{max}}^{2}}{A_{\text{min}}^{2}}=\cfrac{4^{2}}{2^{2}}=\cfrac{4}{1}\)

In short,

\(\cfrac { I _ { \max } } { I _ { \min } } = \left( \cfrac { \sqrt { \cfrac { I _ { 1 } } { I _ { 2 } } } + 1 } { \sqrt { \cfrac { I _ { 1 } } { I _ { 2 } } } - 1 } \right) ^ { 2 } = \left( \cfrac { \sqrt { \cfrac { 9 } { 1 } } + 1 } { \sqrt { \cfrac { 9 } { 1 } } - 1 } \right) = \cfrac { 4 } { 1 }\)
question_plain_title: The ratio of intensities of two waves is 9 : 1. They are producing interference. The ratio of maximum and minimum intensities will be
explanation_plain_text:
Intensity of a wave is proportional to square of its amplitude i.e.

i.e.

i.e.

quest_title: When \(NH_{4} Cl\) is added to \(NH_{4} OH\) solution, the dissociation of ammonium hydroxide is reduced. It is due to
explanation_txt:
Due to common ion effect.

\(NH_4OH \leftrightharpoons NH_4^+ + OH^-\)

\(NH_4Cl \to NH_4^+ + Cl^- \)

Due to excess of \(Cl^-\) ions in soluiton, formation of \(NH_4OH\) is favoured as per Le-chateliar's principle.
question_plain_title: When is added to solution, the dissociation of ammonium hydroxide is reduced. It is due to
explanation_plain_text:
Due to common ion effect.

Due to excess of ions in soluiton, formation of is favoured as per Le-chateliar's principle.

quest_title: The net capacitance of system of capacitors in fig. between points \(\text{A}\) and \(\text{B}\) is
explanation_txt:
Upper 2\(\mu \mathrm{F} \,\,\&\,\, 2 \mu \mathrm{F}\) are in series so
\(C^{\prime}=\cfrac{2 \times 2}{2+2}=\cfrac{2 \times 2}{4}=1\)
Now, 1\(\mu \mathrm{F} \,\,\&\,\, 1 \mu \mathrm{F}\) are in parallel

\(\begin{aligned} \text { So, } & C^{\prime}=1+1 \\ & C^{\prime}=2 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}\)

\(\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad C_{A B} &=1+1 \\ C_{A B} &=2 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: Drift velocity \(v_{d}\) varies with the intensity of electric field as per the relation
explanation_txt:
\(v_{d}=\cfrac{i}{n e A}=\cfrac{J}{n e}=\cfrac{\sigma E}{n e}=\cfrac{E}{\rho n e}\) where \(\sigma\) and \(\rho\) are conductivity and resistivity of material.

\( { \therefore v _ { d } \propto E }\)

explanation_txt:
When the coil is rotated through \(180^{\circ}, \)
\(\Delta \phi=2 \phi\)
\(\text { And again, } \phi=\mu i \)
\(\text { Charge in current } \Delta i=2 \)
This causes a deflection of 14 unit.

\(=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi^{2}\left(1020 \times 10^{3}\right)^{2} \times 420 \times 10^{-12}}\)
\(=5.8 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{H}\)
